question: Frank, do you think you could give me a hand with these bags?
answer: I'm not a doorman, Miss Barrett. I'm a building superintendent.

question: You're also a human being, Frank.
answer: Okay, okay. It's not my job, but what the hell. I'll do you a favor. He takes the grocery bags from her.

question: Thank you, Frank. I'll get the hang of this eventually.
answer: Hiya, Oscar. What do you say, slugger? That's a good-looking kid you got there, Ms. Barrett.

question: Thank you, Frank. Oh, are you ever going to fix the radiator in my bedroom? I asked you last week.
answer: Didn't I do it?

question: No, you didn't, Frank.
answer: Okay, that's no problem.

question: Ready?
answer: I'm ready.

question: Then let's do it.
answer: How you doin', kids?

question: He-Man couldn't make it today. That's why we're here. Well, a lot of people have trouble believing in the paranormal. I'm watching you. Song.
answer: That's it, Ray. I've had it. No more parties. I'm tired of taking abuse from over-privileged nine-year-olds.

question: Come on, Winston. We can't quit now. The holidays are coming up. It's our best season.
answer: Give it up, Ray. You're living in the past. Ghostbusters doesn't exist anymore. In a year these kids won't even remember who we are.

question: Ungrateful little Yuppie larvae. After all we did for this city.
answer: Yeah, what did we do, Ray? The last real job we had we bubbled up a hundred foot marshmallow man and blew the top three floors off an uptown highrise.

question: He turns TO CAMERA and talks to his viewers in a suavely engaging tone, understated and intimate. Hi, welcome back to the 'World of the Psychic,' I'm Peter Venkman and I'm chatting with my guest, author, lecturer and of course, psychic, Milton Anglund. Milt, your new book is called The End of the World. Isn't that kind of like writing about gum disease. Yes, it could happen, but do you think anybody wants to read a book about it? Okay, so can you tell us when it's going to happen or do we have to buy the book? This year? That's cutting it a little close, isn't it? I mean, just from a sales point of view, the book just came out, right? So you're not even looking at the paperback release for maybe a year. And it's going to be at least another year after that if the thing has movie-of-the-week or mini-series potential. You would have been better off predicting 1992 or even '94 just to be safe. Well, for your sake, I hope you're right. But I think my other guest may disagree with you. Elaine, you had another date in mind? Valentine's Day. That's got to be a bummer. Where did you get that date, Elaine? Your alien had a room in the Holiday Inn? No, you can't, and I think that's the whole problem with aliens; you just can't trust them. You may get some nice ones occasionally like Starman or E.T., but most of them turn out to be some kind of lizard. Anyway, we're just about out of time. Next week on 'World of the Psychic,' hairless pets. Until then, this is Peter Venkman saying ... ... Good night. Where do you find these people? I thought we were having the telekinetic guy who bends the spoons? Skeptical! Norman, I'm a pushover. I think professional wrestling is real. What's all this? The Mayor! He's a friend of mine. Lenny! Lenny! It's Pete Venkman!
answer: Can I help you?

question: Yeah, you can get your hand off my chest.
answer: I'm Jack Hardemeyer. I'm the mayor's assistant. What can I do for you?

question: I'm an old friend of the mayor's. I just want to say hello to him.
answer: I know who you are, Doctor Venkman. Busting any ghosts lately?

question: No, that's what I want to talk to the mayor about. We did a little job for the city a while back and we ended up getting sued, screwed and tattooed by deskworms like you.
answer: Look, you stay away from the mayor. Next fall, barring a disaster, he's going to be elected governor of this state and the last thing we need is for him to be associated with two-bit frauds and publicity hounds like you and your friends. You read me?

question: She is carefully cleaning a 19th Century landscape painting, still preoccupied by the extraordinary near-accident with the buggy. Janosz watches her for a moment, then comes up behind her and looks over her shoulder.
answer: Still working on the Turner?

question: Oh, yes, I got in a little late this morning, Janosz.
answer: You know, you are really doing very good work here. I think soon you may be ready to assist me in some of the more important restorations.

question: Thank you, Janosz. I've learned a lot here, but now that my baby's a little older, I was hoping to rejoin the orchestra.
answer: We'll be very sorry to lose you. Perhaps I could take you to lunch today?

question: Actually, I'm not eating lunch today. I have an appointment. In fact, I'd better go.
answer: Every day I ask you, and every day you've got something else to do. Do I have bad breath or something?

question: I'm sorry. Perhaps some other time.
answer: Okay, I'll take a raincheck on that. I think she likes me.

question: ... and then the buggy just suddenly stopped dead in the middle of the street
answer: Did anyone else see this happen?

question: Hundreds of people. Believe me, I didn't imagine this.
answer: I'm not saying you did. In science we always look for the simplest explanation. We'll start with the negative calibration.

question: What are you working on, Egon?
answer: I'm trying to determine whether human emotional states have a measurable effect on the psychomagnetheric energy field. It's a theory Ray and I were working on when we had to dissolve Ghostbusters. They think they're here for marriage counseling. We've kept them waiting for two hours and we've been gradually increasing the temperature in the room. It's up to 95 degrees at the moment. Now my assistant is going to enter and ask them if they'd mind waiting another half-hour. We'll do the happiness index next. I'd like to bring Ray in on your case, if it's all right with you.

question: Okay, whatever you think -- but not Venkman.
answer: Oh no.

question: Do you ever see him?
answer: Occasionally

question: How is he these days?
answer: Venkman? I think he was borderline for a while there. Then he crossed the border.

question: Does he ever mention me?
answer: No. Not that I can recall.

question: Well, we didn't part on very good terms and we sort of lost track of each other when I got married.
answer: Good. Send in the puppy.

question: I thought of calling him after my marriage ended, but --. Anyway, I appreciate you're doing this, Egon This is my address and telephone number. Will you call me?
answer: Certainly.

question: Egon, I'd rather you didn't mention any of this to Peter if you don't mind.
answer: I won't.

question: Thank you.
answer: Now let's see how she reacts when we take away the puppy

question: Now let's see how she reacts when we take away the puppy
answer: Ray's Occult. Yeah ... mmhmm ... What do you need? ... What have I got? I've got alchemy, astrology, apparitions, Bundu Magic Men, demon intercession, U.F.O. abductions, psychic surgery, stigmata, modern miracles, pixie sightings, golden geese, geists, ghosts, I've got it all -- what are you looking for? ... Don't have any. Try the stockyards.

question: Who was that?
answer: Some crank. Looking for goat hooves. Come up with anything?

question: This one's interesting. Berlin, 1939, a flower cart took off by itself and rolled approximately half a kilometer over level ground. Three hundred eyewitnesses.
answer: You might want to check those Duke University mean averaging studies on controlled psychokinesis.

question: Oh, hello, perhaps you could help me. I'm looking for an aerosol love potion I could spray on a certain Penthouse Pet that would make her unconditionally submit to an unusual personal request.
answer: Oh, hiya, Pete.

question: So, no goat hooves, huh?
answer: I knew that voice sounded familiar. What's up? How's it going?

question: Nowhere -- fast. Why don't you lock up and buy me a sub?
answer: Uh, I can't. I'm kind of working on something.

question: Egon!
answer: Hello, Venkman.

question: How've you been? How's teaching? I bet those science chicks really dig that big cranium of yours, huh?
answer: I think they're more interested in my epididymis.

question: I don't even want to know where that is.
answer: Oh, your book came in, Venkman. Magical Paths to Fortune and Power.

question: Great. So what are you guys working on?
answer: Oh, just checking something for an old friend.

question: Who?
answer: Who? Just -- someone we know.

question: Oh, Ray -- Who? Who? Who?
answer: Aaah! Nobody! I can't tell you!

question: Who, Ray?
answer: Dana! Dana Barrett!

question: Hi, Egon.
answer: Hi, Dana. I knew you'd come crawling back to me.

question: Hello, Peter.
answer: You know, Dana, I'm very very hurt that you didn't call me first. I'm still into all this stuff, you know. Haven't you ever seen my show?

question: I have. That's why I didn't call you first.
answer: I can see that you're still very bitter about us, but in the interest of science, I'm going to give it my best shot. Let's go to work, boys. So what happened to Mr. Right? I hear he ditched you and the kid and moved to Europe.

question: He didn't "ditch" me. We had some problems, he got a good offer from an orchestra in England and he took it.
answer: He ditched you. You should've married me, you know.

question: You never asked me, and every time I brought it up you'd get drowsy and fall asleep.
answer: Men are very sensitive, you know. We need to feel loved and desired, too.

question: Well, when you started introducing me as "the old ball and chain," that's when I left.
answer: I may have a few personal problems but one thing I am is a total professional.

question: I may have a few personal problems but one thing I am is a total professional.
answer: He's taking a complete set of body and head measurements of the baby with a tape measure and calipers.

question: What are you going to do, Egon? Knit him a snowsuit?
answer: I'd like to have a stool specimen

question: Yeah, you would. Is that for personal or professional reasons? Okay, kid. Up you go. Help! Please somebody help me! Get him off! Quickly! He's gone completely berserk!
answer: What do you think?

question: There's no doubt about it. He's got his father's looks. The kid is ugly -- extremely ugly. And smelly. You stink! It's just horrible. You are the stinkiest baby I ever smelled. What's his name?
answer: His name is Oscar.

question: Oscar! You poor kid!
answer: Peter, this is serious. I need to know if you think there's anything unusual about him.

question: Unusual? I don't know. I haven't had a lot of experience with babies.
answer: I'll do it.

question: How ya doing?
answer: Fine! It's cutting fine now.

question: Why are you cutting?
answer: Why are we cutting? Uh - boss!

question: NYPRR. What the hell -- ? Help me lift this. Wow! It's an old airshaft. It just goes forever.
answer: Very intense. We need a deeper reading. Somebody has to go down there.

question: Thanks, boys. Keep going -- more -- more -- Lower -- lower -- Gee, this really is deep. Hold it! Steady! He pans the walls with his flashlight, admiring the excellent tilework, and speaks quietly to Venkman and Spengler over his walkie-talkie. This is it, boys, the end of the line. Van Horne Station. The old New York Pneumatic. It's still here.
answer: The New York Pneumatic Railway. It was an experimental subway system. Fan-forced air-trains, built around 1870.

question: This is about as deep as you can go under Manhattan without digging your own hole.
answer: What's the reading?

question: Janosz?
answer: Hello, Dana. I happened to be in the neighborhood and I thought I'd stop by to see if everything's all right with you -- you know, with the blackout and everything? Are you okay? Is the baby all right?

question: We're fine, Janosz.
answer: Do you need anything? You want me to come in?

question: No, everything's fine. Honestly. Thanks anyway.
answer: Okay, just thought I'd check. Good night, Dana. Sleep well. Don't let the bedbugs bite you.

question: I wish I could stay. I feel personally responsible for you being here.
answer: You are personally responsible. If I can get conjugal rights, will you visit me at Sing Sing?

question: Please don't say that. You won't go to prison.
answer: Don't worry about me. I'm like a cat.

question: You mean you cough up hairballs all over the rug?
answer: I'm El Gato. I always land on my feet.

question: Good luck.
answer: Thanks.

question: Sorry, your Honor, but when somebody sets me up like that I can't resist.
answer: I'll ask you again, Dr. Venkman. Why were you digging the hole? And please remember that you're under oath.

question: I had my fingers crossed when they swore me in, but I'm going to tell you the truth. There are things in this world that go way beyond human understanding, things that can't be explained and that most people don't want to know about anyway. That's where we come in.
answer: So what are you saying? That the world of the supernatural is your special province?

question: Does the counsel for the defense wish to make any final arguements?
answer: Your honor, may I approach the bench?

question: Yes.
answer: Can I have some of your water?

question: Get on with it, counselor!
answer: Your honor, ladies and gentlemen of the -- audience. I don't think it's fair to call my clients frauds. Okay, the blackout was a big problem for everybody. I was stuck in an elevator for about three hours and I had to go to the bathroom the whole time, but I don't blame them because once I turned into a dog and they helped me. Thank you.

question: Let's go to work, boys.
answer: Geez, I forgot how heavy these things are.

question: Okay, let's heat 'em up! All right, throwers. Set for full neutronas on stream.
answer: Hey! Why don't you pick on someone your own size?

question: On my signal, boys. Open 'em up -- Now!
answer: Spengs, take the door. Ray, let's try and work them down and into the corner.

question: Watch it! I'm coming under you, Pete. Steady -- watch your streams -- easy now -- Venky, bring him left -- Spengy, pull him down -- trapping -- trapping -- now!
answer: Occupado.

question: What is it, honey?
answer: It's that darn ghost again! I don't know what to do anymore. He just won't leave us alone. I guess we'll just have to move.

question: Don't worry. We're not moving. He is.
answer: Who are you going to call?

question: Yeah, it's not the kind of thing you'd want to hang in the rec room. You know what it needs? A fluffy little white kitten in the corner.
answer: We don't go around altering valuable paintings, Dr. Venkman.

question: Well, I'd make an exception in this case if I were you. I'll let you get back to it. Nice meeting you.
answer: My pleasure.

question: Oh good, you're here. Spengler and I have something really amazing to show you.
answer: It's not that thing you do with your nostrils, is it?

question: We've been studying the stuff that we took from the subway tunnel.
answer: And now you're going to eat it?

question: No, I'm just restoring it to its normal state. Now watch this. You worthless piece of slime!! You ignorant disgusting blob!! You foul, obnoxious muck!! He continues venting his rage on the slime. I've seen some real crud in my time, but you're a chemical disgrace!!
answer: This is what you do with your spare time?

question: This is an incredible breakthrough, Venkman. A psychoreactive substance! Whatever this is, it clearly responds to human emotional states.
answer: 'Mood slime.' We ought to bottle this stuff and sell it.

question: Like a goat on garbage. We're running tests to see if we can get an equally strong positive reaction.
answer: What kind of tests?

question: Well, we sing to it, we talk to it, we say supportive, nurturing things --
answer: You're not sleeping with this stuff, are you?

question: So we'll put a warning on the label. Go ahead. I dare you. Just kidding.
answer: Look at you. I think we got more food on your shirt than we got in your mouth. Still unaware, she routinely reaches over and squirts some bubble bath into the tub. She picks the baby up off the bassinet and turns to place him in the tub. She is just about to lower him into the water when the tub starts to close up around the baby like a hugh mouth. Dana screams, snatches the baby away and runs from the room clutching Oscar to her bosom as the bathtub convulses and vomits up buckets of slime. I'm sorry. Were you on your way out?

question: No, I just got in -- a couple hours ago. Come on in. Are we having a pajama party?
answer: Peter, the bathtub tried to eat Oscar.

question: You know, if anyone else told me that, I'd have serious doubts. But coming from you, I can't honestly say I'm surprised.
answer: I must be losing my mind. At the museum today I could have sworn that terrible painting of Vigo looked right at me.

question: Who could blame him? Were you wearing this nightgown?
answer: I don't know what to do anymore.

question: I'll get Ray and Egon to check out the bathtub. You better stay here. Now this kid has a serious nudity problem. This is Joe Namath's old number, you know. You could get a lot of chicks with this. Just don't pee in it.
answer: Peter, what about the bathtub?

question: We'll take care of that. Ray, Pete. Listen, get over to Dana's right away ... Her bathtub pulled a fast one -- tried to eat the kid.
answer: It was full of this awful pink ooze.

question: Sounds like another slime job ... No, they're all right. They're here now ... Right ... Let me know. They're going over there right now. You might as well make yourself at home. Let me show you around. This is the cuisine de maison -- We may have to wash some of these if you get hungry -- -- but there's no food anyway so forget about it. I have all kinds of carry-out menus if you feel like ordering. Bathroom's right here -- let me just tidy up a few things.
answer: Peter, this is very nice, but you don't have to do any of this, you know.

question: The shower works but it's a little tricky. They're both marked "Hot." It takes a little practice, but at least this one won't try and eat you. Be careful on that sofa -- it's a butt-biter. But the bed's good and I just changed the sheets so if you get tired, feel free. In fact, I think you should definitely plan on spending the night here.
answer: Really? And how would we handle the sleeping arrangements?

question: For me it's best if I sleep on my side and you spoon up right behind me with your arms around me. If we go the other way I'm afraid your hair will be getting in my face all night.
answer: How about you on the sofa and me in bed with the baby.

question: Or we could do that.
answer: Thank you. Poor baby. I think I should put him down now.

question: He stands there transfixed, unable to look away, as a strange and subtle transformation occurs within him. Winston comes up behind him and breaks the spell.
answer: Now that's one ugly dude.

question: Huh? What?
answer: You finished here?

question: What? Yeah.
answer: Are you all right? You coming down with something?

question: Idiot! Move it, you jerk!
answer: Going a little fast, aren't we, Ray?

question: Are you telling me how to drive?
answer: No, I just thought --

question: Well don't think!
answer: Are you crazy, man? You're going to kill somebody!

question: Watch him, Egon. Don't even let him shave. I'm home! I knew it. She cleaned. Are you all squeaky clean now?
answer: Yes, I'm very clean. Did they find anything at my apartment?

question: Nothing. They stayed there all night, went through your personal stuff, made a bunch of long-distance phone calls and cleaned out your refrigerator. And didn't find anything.
answer: They didn't find anything? In the bathtub ... the pink ooze ... nothing? So, what do I do now?

question: Now you get dressed and we go out. I got a babysitter and everything. Trust me, you need it.
answer: I'm not here to date. I can't leave Oscar in a strange place with someone I don't know.

question: It's Janine Melnitz, from my staff. She's one of my most valuable employees.
answer: Does she know anything about babies?

question: Janine Melnitz, are you kidding? Do I have a vase? I brought some of your clothes. Wear something intriguing. I brought along some interesting possibilities.
answer: Okay, but it's not a date. It's a dinner.

question: Did you happen to see some shirts on the floor in here?
answer: I put them in your hamper. I thought they were dirty.

question: Okay, Stinky, this is it. Showdown time. You and me, pal. You think you're smarter than I am? We'll see about that. Oh, hello, Pizza Man! Oh, two larges! I only ordered one. Oh, pepperoni and pineapple. My absolute favorite. I guess I'll have to eat these both by myself. He spots Slimer through the rearview mirror. Okay, let's boogie! Oh migod! I'm sorry. I didn't mean to do that. It was an accident.
answer: What are you doing up here?

question: I was trying to get that smelly green thing. The guys asked me to help out. I'm like the fifth Ghostbuster.
answer: Why would you want to be a Ghostbuster if you're already an accountant?

question: Oh, no, it's just if one of the guys calls in sick or gets hurt.
answer: Have you made any plans yet? You know tomorrow is New Year's Eve.

question: No, I celebrate at the beginning of my corporate tax year which is March first. That way I beat the crowds.
answer: That's very practical. I hate going out on New Year's Eve, too. Well, good night, Louis.

question: Janine, do you feel like maybe getting something to eat on the way home?
answer: I'd like to, but I told Dr. Venkman I'd babysit. Do you want to babysit with me?

question: Here's to -- us. So -- are you making any New Year's resolutions?
answer: I want to stop getting involved with men who aren't good for me.

question: Does that start exactly at midnight tomorrow, or could you hold off for a few days maybe?
answer: For one night in your life, do you think it's possible for us to be completely real?

question: All right, you want to be real? So tell me why did you dump me?
answer: Oh, Peter, I didn't dump you. I just had to protect myself. You really weren't very good for me, you know.

question: I'm not even good for me.
answer: Why do you say things like that? You're so much better than you know.

question: Thank you. If I had that kind of support on a daily basis, I could definitely shape up by the turn of the century.
answer: So why don't you give me a jingle in the year 2000?

question: Let me jingle you right now.
answer: Maybe I should call Janine.

question: I can't believe a person could actually live like this.
answer: So these dwarfs had a limited partnership in a small mining operation and then one day a beautiful princess came to live with them.

question: It's really not a bad place. It just needs a woman's touch.
answer: So they bartered room and board in exchange for housekeeping services, which was a good deal for all of them because then they didn't have to withhold tax and social security, which I'm not saying is right but it's just a story, so I guess it's all right. I can finish this later if you're tired.

question: You're really good with children, Louis. I can tell. Why don't you come here and sit with me?
answer: Okay.

question: Motherhood is a very natural instinct for me. I'd like to have a baby myself. Wouldn't you?
answer: Tonight?

question: That's all right, I see him.
answer: He's just about to pour more champagne when he sees Ray, Egon and Winston coming toward him through the restaurant.

question: You should've been there, Venkman. Absolutely incredible!
answer: Yeah, sorry I missed it. I guess you guys didn't know about the dress code here. It's really kind of a coat and tie place.

question: Hey! It's the Ghostbusters. You're out of uniform, gentlemen
answer: Uh -- well -- we had a little accident, but forget that. We have to see the mayor as soon as possible.

question: Look, Doc, why don't you just go home. You'll get a good night's sleep and then you can give the mayor a call in the morning. Come on.
answer: We're not going anywhere with you. I told you we have to see the mayor now.

question: I'm warning you. You can come along peaceably or --
answer: Hey, don't be an idiot. This is serious.

question: Look, pal, keep this up and you're going with them.
answer: Oh, yeah?

question: Yeah, let's go. You're all under arrest.
answer: Finish your dessert -- it's already paid for. I'll call you.

question: I, Vigo, the scourge of Carpathia --
answer: Yes, the scourge --

question: -- the sorrow of Moldavia --
answer: -- the sorrow --

question: I command you.
answer: I await the word of Vigo.

question: The season of evil begins with the birth of the new year. Bring me the child that I might live again.
answer: Lord Vigo, the mother, Dana, is fine and strong. I was wondering -- well, would it be possible -- if I bring the baby, could I have the woman?

question: You know you really don't have to stay. Peter should be back soon.
answer: Oh no, we don't mind.

question: Excuse me. I think Oscar is up. Louis! She watches in helpless horror. No!! She watches the creature fly off with Oscar, then climbs back through the window assisted by Louis and Janine. Louis, you have to find Peter and tell him what happened.
answer: Where're you going?

question: I knew you would come.
answer: What do you want with my baby?

question: No harm will come to the child. You might even say it's a privilege. He will be the vessel for the spirit of Vigo. And you -- well, you will be the mother of the ruler of the world. Doesn't that sound nice?
answer: If this is what the world will be like, I don't want to live in it.

question: I don't believe we have the luxury of choice.
answer: Everybody has a choice.

question: Not in this case, my dear. Take a look. That's not Gainsborough's Blue Boy up there. He's Vigo!
answer: I don't care who he is. He's not taking my baby. She turns and looks at Vigo, for the first time feeling his power.

question: Come on, Sherm. You're my cousin. Do this for me. I'm begging you.
answer: I can't do it, Louis. It isn't ethical. I could lose my license.

question: Why can't you just have them released? You're a doctor.
answer: I'm a dermatologist. I can't write orders on the psych ward.

question: Sherman, I've done lots of favors for you.
answer: Like what?

question: I got you out of those bad tax shelters.
answer: You were the one who got me in.

question: I fixed you up with Diane Troxler and she put out, didn't she?
answer: Yeah, I had to give her free dermabrasion for a year. Forget it, Louis. I could get in a lot of trouble.

question: I'm telling you, we're all going to be in big trouble if we don't do something fast. That ghost guy came and took my friend's baby and we got to get it back. It's just a scared little baby, Sherm.
answer: Then you should go to the police. I don't believe in any of that stuff.

question: Oh, I pulled a few strings. I wouldn't want to say any more than that. This is my cousin Sherman. Sherm, say hello to the Ghostbusters. I promised him a ride in the car if he got you out.
answer: Hi, it's really great to meet you guys. I know this sounds weird but once I had a dream that my grandfather was standing at the foot of my bed, but I knew it was impossible because he died and he started to tell me that --

question: Hey! Wait! Okay, I'll meet you there.
answer: I thought you were like the fifth Ghostbuster.

question: It won't work. There's no way we could generate enough positive energy to crack that shell.
answer: I can't believe things have gotten so bad in this city that there's no way back. Sure, it's crowded, it's dirty, it's noisy. And there are too many people who'd just as soon step on your face as look at you. But there've got to be a few sparks of sweet humanity left in this burned-out burg. We just have to mobilize it.

question: We need something that everyone can get behind, a symbol --
answer: Something that appeals to the best in each and every one of us --

question: Time is running out, Dana. Soon it will be midnight and the city will be mine -- and Vigo's. Well, mainly Vigo's. But we have a spectacular opportunity to make the best of our relationship.
answer: We don't have a relationship.

question: I know. Marry me, Dana, and together we will raise Vigo as our son. There are many perks that come with being the mother of a living god. I'm sure he will supply for us a magnificent apartment. And perhaps a car and free parking.
answer: I hate and despise you and everything you stand for with all my heart and soul. I could never forgive what you've done to me and my child.

question: Many marriages begin with a certain amount of distance, but after a while I believe we could learn to love each other. Think about it.
answer: I'd rather not.

question: Sorry. No checks. Company policy.
answer: Pretty impressive, huh?

question: It's probably the first thing my grandparents saw when they came to this country.
answer: From where -- Neptune?

question: They came from Ostrov in Eastern Poland.
answer: Ostrov? I've been there. Good party town.
